title: Can I produce a set of metal type to use in an old hand press?
content:
Hi all!

I’m planning to do a “lead typography” course next year.  
I need some links (good ones :-)) about it and if there is a place where (or if is possible-economicly speaking) I can produce a set of metal type to use in an old hand press?

António

 [‹ "Goodie Bag" video blog on Trajan](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012143311/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40093 "Go to previous forum topic") [General Posting Guidelines ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012143311/http:/www.typophile.com/node/17384 "Go to next forum topic")
author: afonseca1974

comments.content: [BriarPress.org](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012143311/http:/www.briarpress.org/) is a great letterpress community with a lot of good info and classifieds where you can purchase metal type. Having metal type made from a digital font is probably not the best way to go (if that’s what you were thinking).

If I’m not mistaken, I believe the Hamilton Wood Type Museum in Two Rivers, Wisconsin sells sets of metal type. You would want to call them to see what sets are up for sale. When I visited, I seem to recall they had more for sale than what appeared on their website.

Just a thought. Happy hunting!

Mark

[www.woodtype.org](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012143311/http:/www.woodtype.org/ "www.woodtype.org")
I know you can do it, as we had a whole much of ’@’ signs cast back when working at a letterpress shop. I just don’t remember the company.
